title: King Curtis Iaukea
text:
Curtis Piehau Iaukea III (September 15, 1937 – December 4, 2010) was an American <a href="professional%20wrestler">professional wrestler</a> better known as King Curtis Iaukea. Iaukea won championships in several of the major regional U.S. promotions, both as a single and in various tag team combinations, during the 1960s. He then competed in the <a href="World%20Wrestling%20Entertainment">World Wrestling Federation</a> (WWF) where he won the <a href="WWF%20Tag%20Team%20Championship">WWF Tag Team Championship</a> with Baron Scicluna. He was also later The Master of the <a href="The%20Dungeon%20of%20Doom">Dungeon of Doom</a> in <a href="World%20Championship%20Wrestling">World Championship Wrestling</a> (WCW). Under the name "Iau Kea" he appeared in the film "<a href="The%20Three%20Stooges%20Go%20Around%20the%20World%20in%20a%20Daze">The Three Stooges Go Around the World in a Daze</a>" with <a href="Moe%20Howard">Moe Howard</a> declaring "That's not a man! That's a committee!".
Early life.
He was the great grandson of Colonel <a href="Curtis%20P.%20Iaukea">Curtis P. Iaukea</a>, a royal chamberlain and diplomat to the court of King <a href="Kal%C4%81kaua">Kalākaua</a> and Queen <a href="Liliuokalani">Liliuokalani</a> and son of <a href="Honolulu%20Police%20Department">Honolulu Police Department</a> Inspector Curtis Iaukea II. He attended <a href="Punahou%20School">Punahou School</a> and the <a href="University%20of%20California%20Berkeley">University of California Berkeley</a> as an economics major where he lettered as a <a href="Lineman%20%28American%20football%29">lineman</a> until he dropped out. He played as a <a href="Tackle%20%28American%20football%29">tackle</a> for the <a href="BC%20Lions">BC Lions</a> from 1958-1959 and the <a href="Montreal%20Alouettes">Montreal Alouettes</a> in 1959. He was also in camp with the <a href="Oakland%20Raiders">Oakland Raiders</a> in 1960 before being cut.
Professional wrestling career.
Iaukea came to Don Owen's Pacific Northwest territory, commonly known as Portland Wrestling in 1961, wrestling under the moniker Prince Kuhio. Teaming with Haru Sasaki, the two would capture the NWA Pacific Northwest Tag Titles on January 19, 1962, holding them for two months. A year later, while traveling between Oregon and the Hawaiian Islands, King Curtis would capture the NWA Pacific Northwest Heavyweight Title on September 5, 1963,
In <a href="Australia">Australia</a>, King Curtis was a part of the <a href="face%20%28professional%20wrestling%29">face</a> <a href="tag%20team">tag team</a> known as the People's Army with <a href="Mark%20Lewin">Mark Lewin</a> and <a href="Spiros%20Arion">Spiros Arion</a>.
His first sojourns to Australia were in the 1964–1965 season, where he was a <a href="heel%20%28professional%20wrestling%29">Heel</a>. He was teamed with <a href="Skull%20Murphy">Skull Murphy</a>. King Curtis initially wrestled as Curtis Iaukea in his first run in Australia. The King Curtis tag was the one that stuck as he feuded against Mark Lewin. After becoming a fan favorite in the seventies, King Curtis feuded against <a href="Tiger%20Jeet%20Singh">Tiger Jeet Singh</a> and the Tojo brothers from Japan." King Curtis was also a member of an alliance known as "The People's Army."
After retiring in the mid-1980s, he turned to <a href="manager%20%28professional%20wrestling%29">managing</a>. In ICW, known as King Curtis, he managed <a href="Kevin%20Sullivan%20%28wrestler%29">Kevin Sullivan</a> and Mark Lewin, taking on the <a href="Glossary%20of%20professional%20wrestling%20terms%23Gimmick">gimmick</a> of a crazed cult leader. His faction feuded with <a href="Joe%20Savoldi">Joe Savoldi</a> and <a href="Austin%20Idol">Austin Idol</a>. In the 80's, he also appeared with Sullivan in Championship Wrestling from Florida as "The Chairman of the Board". Curtis Iaukea re-appeared briefly in the WWF promotion as the Wizard, a manager and mouthpiece for <a href="Kamala%20%28wrestler%29">Kamala</a> and <a href="Sika%20Anoa%27i">Sika</a>. He also appeared briefly in <a href="WCW">WCW</a> as 'The Master' of the Dungeon of Doom stable in the mid-90s.
